question: Take that back.
answer: All right, I take it back. There's only one thing we can do. We've got to get rid of it. We've got to get an abortion.

question: We've got to get an abortion?
answer: Yeah. My brother Art got his girlfriend one once.

question: It's already planned, Mike. It's going to cost $150 at the Free Clinic.
answer: Doesn't sound free to me. So you want me to pay for it?

question: Half. Okay? Seventy-five dollars. And a ride to the clinic.
answer: Seventy-five dollars, and a ride. Okay.

question: Hello... is Mike there? Hi, Mrs. Barrett. Is Linda there? Okay. Thanks. Brad! Hey, wait a second! Yeah. This is it. I have some shopping to do.
answer: See you later.

question: Thanks a lot, Brad. I really appreciate it. This is going to hurt, isn't it? Does it hurt more to have a baby? Uh, my boyfriend said held be waiting downstairs. Brad!
answer: Since when do you shop at the Flea Market anyway?

question: Brad. Please don't tell Mom and Dad...
answer: Who did it? You're not going to tell me, are you?

question: No.
answer: All right, then. It's your secret.

question: I really thought he would show up. I waited... and waited... and waited...
answer: That little prick.

question: Then I called his house, and his mother told me he was in the garage helping his father.
answer: That little prick.

question: I paid for it and everything.
answer: There goes your stereo for another year. Mike Damone is a no-brain little prick. I'm not letting him get away with this.

question: Don't do anything, Linda. I'd rather just forget about it. I don't even like the guy.
answer: Stacy, he's not a guy. He's a little prick!

question: Shhhhhhhhhit. Hi... girls.
answer: Damone? What happened between you and Stacy?

question: Let me tell you something, Rat. Sometimes girls just go haywire. It was a month ago, I've been trying to think of a way to tell you ever since. We started messing around and... ... something happened. It's all over with. It's no big deal. I never called her again. If you ask me, she's pretty aggressive. You understand what I'm saying?
answer: No Damone. I don't understand.

question: She wasn't really your girlfriend anyway.
answer: Hey fuck you Damone. There's a lot of girls out there and you mess around with Stacy. What have you got to prove?

question: Jesus. I'm sorry.
answer: I always stick up for you. Whenever people say 'Aw, that Damone is a loudmouth' -- and they say that a lot -- I say 'You just don't know Damone.' When someone says you're an idiot, I tell them 'Damone's not an idiot. You just don't know him.' Well, you know, Damone, maybe they do know you pretty good. And I'm just finding out.

question: Fine. Get lost. All right, Rat. You want to do something about it? Well come on.
answer: You come on.

question: Hey, mon, can I use the bathroom?
answer: Go ahead. Just make it quick.

question: Totally.
answer: It's the first door on your left.

question: I can't find it, mon!
answer: It's the first door on your left!

question: On the ledge?
answer: First door on your left!

question: I want money. And I want it all -- now.
answer: They empty and close the big safe here at midnight.

question: I know this store. I know where the safe is. Over there behind the donut case. Now move!
answer: I'm instructed to tell you that we are on a video alarm system and there are other hidden cameras in the store ...

question: Just give me the money. Move it.
answer: Okay. I just started here, and they just taught me the procedure. I'll give you the money, just let me figure this out.

question: Move it. Move it. Let's go, stupid.
answer: You motherfucker. Get off my fuckin' case.

question: Another summer of working at Swenson's.
answer: Come on. There's lots of men around here. Keep your eyes open.

question: You know, Linda. I've finally figured it out. It's not sex I want. Anyone can have sex.
answer: What do you want?

question: I want romance.
answer: Romance in Ridgemont? We don't even get cable TV.

question: Go away, Curtis. If you can't knock, I can't hear you. That's better. Come in. Mr... Mr. Hand.
answer: That's right, Jeff. Mind if I come in? Thank you, Mr. and Mrs. Spicoli. Were you going somewhere tonight, Jeff?

question: Yeah. The Graduation Dance Mr. Hand. It's the last school event of the year.
answer: I'm afraid we've got some things to discuss here, Jeff.

question: Did I do something wrong, Mr. Hand?
answer: Do you want to sit there, Jeff?

question: I don't know. I guess so.
answer: Fine. You sit right here on your bed. I'll use the chair here. As I explained to your parents just a moment ago, and to you many times since the very beginning of the school year -- I don't like to spend my time waiting for late students, or detention cases. I'd rather be preparing the lesson. According to my calculations, Mr. Spicoli, you wasted a total of eight hours of my time this year. And rest assured that is a kind estimate. Now, Mr. Spicoli, comes a rare moment for me. Now I have the unique pleasure of squaring our account. Tonight, you and I are going to talk in great detail about the Davis Agreement, all the associated treaties, and the American Revolution in particular. Now if you can just turn to Chapter 47 of Lord of Truth And Liberty.

question: Hey, it's in my locker, Mr. Hand.
answer: Well, then, I'm glad I remembered to bring an extra copy just for you.

question: ... so, like, when Jefferson went before the people what he was saying was 'Hey, we left this place in England because it was bogus, and if we don't come up with some cool rules ourself, we'll be bogus, too!' Right?
answer: Very close, Jeff. I think I've made my point with you tonight.

question: Hey, Mr. Hand, can I ask you a question?
answer: What's that?

question: Do you have a guy like me every year? A guy to... I don't know, make a show of. Teach other kids lessons and stuff?
answer: Well, you'll find out next year.

question: No way, mon. When I graduate U.S. history I ain't even coming over to your side of the building.
answer: If you graduate.

question: You're gonna flunk me?!
answer: Don't worry, Spicoli. You'll probably squeak by.

question: All right! Oh, yeah! Aloha, Mr. Hand!
answer: Aloha, Spicoli.

question: Where's Doug?
answer: He's not coming.

question: Not coming? What happened?
answer: He says he's got to stay in Chicago. He says I should visit him sometimes.

question: Sometime?
answer: Yeah, like maybe never.

question: But what are you going to do?
answer: Well I might go to Dartmouth.

question: Dartmouth?!
answer: I didn't tell anyone I applied cause I never thought I'd make it.

question: I can't believe it! But what about Doug?
answer: There's a world of guys out there. I just wish I didn't have to date any of them.

question: Get us jobs over there, Brad! You can do it!
answer: Since when do you guys want to work at 7-11?

question: Come on, Brad! It would be great! All of us together!
answer: Well, 7-11 is a tremendous operation. It's really changed, man. They've got great food, great magazines, videogames... it's class. Total class.

question: Yeah, man, all the little punks from junior high have taken over the place.
answer: Hey, Thompson! Wendell! Get a job!

question: Hey Mark! Turn around! Come over here!
answer: You. Sit.

question: Hi, Mark.
answer: Hi, Stacy. How are you?

question: I'm fine. Mark, I'm so glad you came over here because I want you to know something. I just thought I would tell you that I really enjoyed getting to know you this year.
answer: Yeah? About fifty people I didn't know wrote that in my annual.

question: I know everybody says it, but I really mean it.
answer: Really?

question: Yeah. I want you to have this picture, so you won't forget what I look like. And so you'll remember to call me over the summer.
answer: Well, I don't know, I may be doing some traveling this summer. I don't know how much I'll be around... But I'll give you a call sometime.
